$(document).ready(function () {
        var logConsole = function (str) {
            console.log(str);
        };
        if ($('#tabPortlet_280249 .divTabEdit').val() == "True") {
            var isModern = ('True');
            if(isModern.toLowerCase() == "true")
            {
                var tabObj = $('#tabPortlet_280249 ');
                var tabM = $('#ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl23_divTabs').attr('portlet') == 'tab';

                function activate() {
                    $(tabObj).scrollingTabs({                 
                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl23_divTabs_0","title":"Distance Learning","content":"The State of Minnesota has ordered Distance Learning for schools to begin on Monday, March 30 and to continue through at least Monday, May 4. Distance Learning information was sent to all families on March 25. Detailed information can be found at sowashco.org/distancelearning.
\n
\nSouth Washington County Schools buildings will remain closed to students, except for emergency meals and child care, which will continue to be provided during this time. 
\n
\nFor information about the Governor’s stay at home order, visit https://mn.gov/governor/covid-19/.
\n
Technology Help\nHaving issues with your device can be very frustrating. Find Troubleshooting Tips and Tricks with your school issued devices on the Technology Resources page.
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl23_divTabs_1","title":"Technology Help","content":"
Having issues with your device can be very frustrating. Find Troubleshooting Tips and Tricks with your school issued devices on the Technology Resources page.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl23_divTabs_2","title":"Emergency Child Care","content":"
Following the closure of all schools in the state of Minnesota, South Washington County Schools has opened Emergency Child Care at no cost to families who qualify. Emergency Child Care is open to currently enrolled students in kindergarten-grade 5 for parents or guardians who are defined as one of the workers listed below. 
\n
\nParents or guardians who qualify should provide proof of their employment through (1) a letter from their employer or (2) an employment badge.\n\n    
Home care workers \n    
Personal care assistants \n    
Ambulance/emergency \n    
Direct care and treatment \n    
Other emergency staff, including:\n    \n        
First responders \n        
Firefighters \n        
Personnel providing correctional services \n        
Essential court personnel \n        
Minnesota State Veterans Homes staff \n        
State and local public health agency employees \n        
MNsure Navigators \n        
County financial/eligibility workers \n        
County case managers \n        
Or any county staff in emergency management or health and human services\n        
and more\n    \n    \n\n
Tier 2 Employees\n\n    
Educators\n    
Child care workers\n    
MNDoT employees\n    
State and local essential IT personnel\n    
Substance disorder treatment workers\n    
Medical examiners\n    
National Guard (if activated)\n    
Water treatment/wastewater operators\n    
Day-to-day operations for gas and electric utilities\n    
Emergency response for gas and electric utilities\n    
Food distribution workers (including in-store personnel)\n    
Public works workers\n    
and more\n\n
If you are interested in Emergency Child Care and are employed in one of the fields listed above, you may register here. Students cannot be dropped off without registration.
\n
\nOnce registration is complete, you will be assigned to a child care site. Child care is available from 6:30 a.m. to 6 p.m. Monday through Friday. Breakfast and lunch will be provided at no cost. Please be prepared to provide a letter from your employer or an employee identification card or badge to verify your employment as an emergency responder. 
\n
\nThank you for all you do for our community. We will provide additional information as it becomes available. For the latest information, please review sowashco.org/covid19. ","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl23_divTabs_3","title":"Emergency Free Meals","content":"
South Washington County Schools is providing some meal options for families in our community including food delivery and meal pick-up sites.\n
Food Delivery\n
Food delivery requests are reserved for families who do not have transportation or those who have a medically fragile child. Deliveries are made through the SoWashCo Cares Foundation and are based on food and staff availability. To be added to the waitlist, register here.\n
Food Pick-up Sites\n
South Washington County Schools is offering meal options to anyone under the age of 18 or those enrolled in our Next Step program. Registration is no longer required. \n
Instructions\n\n    
\n    
Meal pick-up sites are available to families whose children are under the age of 18 and are in need of food assistance\n    \n    
\n    
Families who choose the pick-up option no longer need to have their child with them.  Simply provide verification of your child through a student ID badge, the ability to log into Schoology or SeeSaw, a letter regarding qualification for free or reduced-price lunch, an email from your student’s teacher, etc.\n    \n    
\n    
The meal sites will be open for the time referenced or until the food runs out\n    \n    
\n    
Please stay in your vehicle, and a nutrition services staff member will bring you the appropriate number of meals\n    \n    
\n    
If you do not have a vehicle, please stay outside the building, and a staff member can assist you\n    \n    
\n    
Families should plan their meals for the week. Starting Monday, April 27 on Monday and Tuesday pick up dates, you will receive six meals (three breakfasts, three lunches). On Wednesday and Thursday pick up dates, you will receive eight meals (four breakfasts, four lunches). \n    
\n    
 \n    \n\n
Meal Pick-up Sites and Schedule\n\n    
Crestview Elementary (7830 80th St. S., Cottage Grove, MN)\n    \n        
11 a.m.-1 p.m., Mondays and Wednesdays\n        
Locate the carpool lane on the east side of the building (closest to park) and go to door number two.  Please line up alongside the sidewalk and remain in your vehicle. A volunteer staff member will then bring you the appropriate number of meals.\n    \n    \n    
Cottage Grove Middle School (9775 Indian Blvd. S., Cottage Grove, MN)\n    \n        
4-6 p.m., Tuesdays and Thursdays  \n        
Enter Cottage Grove Middle School through the main entrance on the north side of the building. Follow the carpool lane until you reach the driveway to the loading dock area. Follow this around to the bus entrance where the meals are to be picked up, which is located on the south side of the building. Please line up alongside the sidewalk and remain in your vehicle. A volunteer staff member will then bring you the appropriate number of meals.\n    \n    \n    
Lake Middle School (3133 Pioneer Dr., Woodbury, MN)\n    \n        
11 a.m.-1 p.m., Mondays and Wednesdays\n        
Enter Lake Middle School from Pioneer Drive and continue to go straight until you reach the other side of the building where the bus entry is located. Please line up alongside the sidewalk and remain in your vehicle. A volunteer staff member will then bring you the appropriate number of meals.\n    \n    \n    
Starting Tuesday, April 28 Woodbury Elementary School (1251 School Dr., Woodbury, MN 55125)\n    \n        
11 a.m.-1 p.m., Tuesdays and Thursdays\n        
Locate door number two on the west side of the building. Please line up alongside the sidewalk and remain in your vehicle. A volunteer staff member will then bring you the appropriate number of meals. 
\n        \n    \n    \n\n
\n
Additional Information and Support\n\n    
The latest information in English is available at sowashco.org/covid19\n    
For more information in Hmoob, please contact Mee Yang at myang022@sowashco.org\n    
For more information in Español please contact Tania Sprague at tsprague@sowashco.org\n    
For more information in Soomaali, please contact Hassan Yusuf at hyusuf@sowashco.org\n\n
\n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl23_divTabs_4","title":"Building Restrictions","content":"Beginning Thursday, March 19, all school buildings and district educational sites will be locked and closed to the public without an appointment. If your school has not already communicated with you about available times to pick up items or medications, please watch for more information coming from your child’s school or the health staff.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl23_divTabs_5","title":"Middle School Devices","content":"
South Washington County Schools prepared students and families for Distance Learning by providing a district-issued Chromebook for all middle school students. Middle school teachers will deliver instruction through an online learning management tool called Schoology. The district has used Schoology for the past three years and is an important learning tool to provide quality Distance Learning at your home. 
\n
\nIf your student was not able to pick-up a Chromebook, please contact your principal. \nA number of providers are offering free internet and we encourage families to access these resources.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl23_divTabs_6","title":"Internet Accessibility for Families","content":"\n
South Washington County Schools is preparing for the possibility of Distance Learning if a longer-term school cancellation is necessary. Our goal is for each middle and high school student to have access to a device and internet during Distance Learning. Families who do not have access to a device and/or internet are encouraged to access the following resources. 
\n
\nComcast is offering two months free to new Internet Essentials customers in response to anticipated emergency measures associated with the COVID-19.\n
\nXfinity WiFi hotspots across the country will be available to anyone who needs them for free – including non-Xfinity Internet subscribers. For a map of Xfinity WiFi hotspots, visit www.xfinity.com/wifi. Once at a hotspot, consumers should select the “xfinitywifi” network name in the list of available hotspots, and then launch a browser.
\n
\nCenturyLink offers Lifeline, a low-cost internet service, to individuals who qualify.
\n
\nSouth Washington County Schools is providing this information as a courtesy to families, not as an endorsement of the services provided. Additional internet resources will be shared as we become aware of them. ","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl23_divTabs_7","title":"School events, activities, athletics and student trips","content":"
All activities are canceled through at least May 4, including:\n\n    
Athletics, including games, tournaments and practices\n    
Plays\n    
Concerts\n    
District events\n    
School assemblies\n    
Group fundraisers\n    
Meetings \n    
Rental agreements held by outside organizations for meetings and activities in a District 833 building\n    
All local, domestic and international field trips\n\n
There have also been several questions about events and activities later in the school year. We are not ready to make any decisions that far out due to the fluid nature of this pandemic.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl23_divTabs_8","title":"State Assessments and ACT Testing","content":"Based on a March 20, 2020 announcement by U.S. Department of Education Secretary Betsy DeVos and Governor Walz’s Executive Order, districts will no longer administer statewide assessments (ACCESS, Alternate ACCESS, MCA, and MTAS) for the remainder of the 2019–20 school year.
\n
\nAdditionally, the ACT Plus Writing college entrance test that was originally scheduled for all 11th grade students on April 7 has been cancelled. The district is working with the ACT organization to determine alternative testing options for current 11th grade students. ACT does not permit testing at home. Once an alternative is finalized we will share it with you.
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl23_divTabs_9","title":"Family Resources","content":"
A number of community services are also offering emergency services at this time, including food resources, mental health resources and how to explain the coronavirus to children. 
\n
\nView Family Resources","active":false,"disabled":false}],// required,
                        propPaneId: 'paneId', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propTitle: 'title', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propActive: 'active', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propDisabled: 'disabled', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propContent: 'content', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        tabMode : tabM,
                        scrollToTabEdge: false, // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        disableScrollArrowsOnFullyScrolled: false // optional- pass in default value for demo purposes
                    }).on('ready.scrtabs', function() {
                        $('#'+this.id+' .tab-pane').attr('tabindex',0);
                    });
                };

                activate();
            }
        }
    });

$(document).ready(function () {
        var logConsole = function (str) {
            console.log(str);
        };
        if ($('#tabPortlet_280248 .divTabEdit').val() == "True") {
            var isModern = ('True');
            if(isModern.toLowerCase() == "true")
            {
                var tabObj = $('#tabPortlet_280248 ');
                var tabM = $('#ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl30_divTabs').attr('portlet') == 'tab';

                function activate() {
                    $(tabObj).scrollingTabs({                 
                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl30_divTabs_0","title":"We Are Essential","content":"Governor Tim Walz announced a stay-at-home order that is currently scheduled through Monday, May 4. This order does not apply to school district employees. All K-12 schools, and staff, are considered essential. 
\n
\nStaff who are scheduled to work should plan to work on-site or remotely, if their job duties allow with supervisor approval. At this time, staff will continue to be paid but must be working and available by phone and email during their regularly scheduled hours. Staff may also be assigned new duties that are not usually part of their regular position to support our essential operations. Staff who received approval to work remotely may also be called in to work on-site.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl30_divTabs_1","title":"Work from Home","content":"
Eligible staff are able to work remotely with supervisor approval. Please see our general guidelines below.\n\n    
Please work with your supervisor to determine if you are eligible to work remotely.\n    
Between Friday, March 27 and Monday, May 4 buildings are only open to staff on Mondays and Fridays to support Distance Learning and other required work duties.\n    \n        
These restrictions do not apply to maintenance, custodial staff, engineers, principals or their designee and office coordinators.\n    \n    \n    
Staff who work remotely must be available by phone and email during their regularly scheduled work hours, but may complete their work at any time.\n    
Staff must be as responsive to emails, text or other communication methods as if they were on-site.\n    
Productivity will be measured by your supervisor in the same manner as if you were on-site.\n    
All staff eligible to work remotely should ensure their equipment, internet access and communications tools are working. Technology tools include, but are not limited to:\n    \n        
Outlook Webmail (Instructions)\n        
Mitel Phone App\n        
Schoology - Secondary staff (click on Login Here)\n        \n            
Schoology Tutorial Schoology Course Access Code: X273-KQBK-J5G78\n        \n        \n        
Seesaw - Elementary\n        
Infinite Campus Messenger\n        
Google Apps (Forms, Docs, Sheets, etc)\n        
Webex intro\n        
Translation and Interpretation\n        
Lexikeet Virtual Training\n        
Language Line\n        
Technology Services has opened up a new phone line for technical and teaching and learning support that is now available to staff who work remotely. Call 651-425-3000.\n        
The same confidentiality that applies to work on-site also applies to work off-site.\n        
It’s OK to take a break to refresh your mind, make some coffee or tea and hug your dog.\n    \n    \n\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl30_divTabs_2","title":"Sign-up To Help","content":"
If a staff member has not been assigned specific work duties by your supervisor and wish to help, please review our sign-up form so that we can gather a list of staff to assist in emergency child care, food service and more.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl30_divTabs_3","title":"Families First Coronavirus Response Act","content":"All District employees are considered essential employees.  Staff who are scheduled to work should plan to work on-site or remotely, if their job duties allow with supervisor approval. At this time, staff will continue to be paid but must be working and available by phone and email during their regularly scheduled hours. Staff may also be assigned new duties that are not usually part of their regular position to support our essential operations. Staff who receive approval to work remotely may also be called in to work on-site.\n\n\n
Families First Coronavirus Response Act\n
The Families First Coronavirus Response Act was recently signed into law and effective April 1, 2020 and the provisions end on December 31, 2020.\n
Paid Sick Leave\n
All employees, regardless of how long they have worked for the district, are eligible for paid sick leave.  Full-time employees will be eligible for up to 80 hours paid sick leave due to a COVID-19 qualifying reason.  Part-time employees are entitled to paid sick leave based on the average number of hours worked in a two week period.\n\n    
100% pay for qualifying reasons #1-3 below (capped at $511 daily and $5,110 total)\n    
2/3 pay for qualifying reasons #4 and #6 below (capped at $200 daily and $2,000 total)\n    
Up to 10 weeks more of paid sick leave and expanded family and medical leave paid at 2/3 for qualifying reason #5 for up to $200 daily and $12,000 total)\n    \n        
Must be employed with the district for at least 30 days and remote work is not available\n    \n    \n\n
Qualifying Reasons\n\n    
The employee is subject to a federal, state, or local quarantine or isolation order related to COVID-19\n    
The employee has been advised by a health care provider to self-quarantine due to concerns related to COVID-19\n    
The employee is experiencing symptoms of COVID-19 and seeking medical diagnosis\n    
The employee is caring for an individual who is subject to either #1 or #2 above\n    
The employee is caring for his/her child if the school or place of care of the child has been closed, or the childcare provider of such son/daughter is unavailable (and remote work is not available)\n    
The employee is experiencing any other substantially similar condition specified by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services\n\n
Employees requesting Emergency Sick Pay and/or FMLA should complete the attached Sick Pay & LOA Request and submit it with the proper documentation (details on the request form) to their HR Specialist.  Please note that FMLA should be requested only if absence will exceed 11 days.  Employees are encouraged to contact their HR Specialist with questions. \n\n    
Download the COVID Sick Pay and LOA Request Form
\n    \n        
Submit the completed form with supporting documentation to your HR Specialist for approval.\n    \n    \n    
Employee Rights: Paid Sick Leave and Expanded Family and Medical Leave\n\n
Choosing to self-quarantine with no medical diagnosis is not a qualifying reason for Sick Pay.  If an employee continues to choose not to work, they will need to continue to use PAL/Vacation/Personal Business and then will fall into an unpaid status.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl30_divTabs_4","title":"Substitute Teachers","content":"\n    
An email was sent to substitute teachers on March 18.\n    
Substitute teachers who are long term subs should continue as though they are the teacher in the classroom.\n    
Daily call subs do not continue on payroll.\n    
Long term subs will continue to be paid per their contract. \n    
Any subs who are not on a contract and are asked to work will need to voucher. \n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl30_divTabs_5","title":"Building Access","content":"
Upon further evaluation, and with the Governor’s latest orders, we are now limiting building access to staff through Monday, May 4. Buildings are now only open to staff on Mondays and Fridays to support Distance Learning and other required work duties. We will continue to evaluate building access restrictions and make adjustments as necessary. If you received approval to work remotely, please do so.
\n
\nThe two-week building restrictions do not apply to: \n\n    
Maintenance, custodial staff and engineers\n    
Principals, or their designee, and their office coordinators\n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl30_divTabs_6","title":"Staff Pay","content":"At this time, staff will continue to be paid but must be working and available by phone and email during their regularly scheduled hours. 
\n
\nAll District employees are considered essential employees. Staff who are scheduled to work should plan to work on-site or remotely, if their job duties allow with supervisor approval. Staff may also be assigned new duties that are not usually part of their regular position to support our essential operations. Staff who receive approval to work remotely may also be called in to work on-site.
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl30_divTabs_7","title":"Staff Wellness","content":"
Check out the Employee Wellness Hotspot for new resources, challenges and inspiration to keep you healthy and calm during these unsettling times. \n\n    
April Small Habits Challenge\n    
May STEP Challenge\n    
Free Wellbeats on demand fitness\n    
Employee Assistance Program\n","active":false,"disabled":false}],// required,
                        propPaneId: 'paneId', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propTitle: 'title', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propActive: 'active', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propDisabled: 'disabled', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propContent: 'content', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        tabMode : tabM,
                        scrollToTabEdge: false, // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        disableScrollArrowsOnFullyScrolled: false // optional- pass in default value for demo purposes
                    }).on('ready.scrtabs', function() {
                        $('#'+this.id+' .tab-pane').attr('tabindex',0);
                    });
                };

                activate();
            }
        }
    });

a.title: Focused on Prevention
a.style: text-decoration-line: none; background-color: white; outline: 0px; font-size: 14px;
a.span: South Washington County Schools Focused on Prevention

div.p: The outbreak of the new coronavirus disease, known as COVID-19, has people concerned around the world, including staff and families at South Washington County Schools.

COVID-19 is a respiratory illness caused by a coronavirus, and health officials are learning more about it every day. Symptoms are similar to other respiratory illnesses and include fever, cough and shortness of breath. More common infections, like the cold and flu, also have similar symptoms.

Though we do not have any cases of COVID-19 in our school communities, South Washington County Schools continues to plan and prepare for the possibility. We are in close communication with the Minnesota Department of Health and will follow all guidelines of local health officials and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

div.h3: South Washington County SchoolsIndependent School District #833
